languageKey.label: kreXX Debugger

File
True
False
Normal
Deep
Full edit
Display only
Do not display

Here you can enter your own alias function for \krexx::open(). Example: When you enter 'gue', the function will be \krexx::gue($myObject); [or krexx($myObject, 'gue');], which only devs can use who have set the same value.This is useful, to prevent other devs from calling your debug functions.
Shall kreXX try to analyse the protected properties of a class? This may result in a lot of output.
Shall kreXX try to analyse the private properties of a class? This may result in a lot of output.
Shall kreXX try to analyse possible traversable data? Depending on the underlying framework this info might be covered by the debug callback functions.

Comma-separated list of used debug callback functions. A lot of frameworks offer these, toArray and toString being the most common. kreXX will try to call them, if they are available and display their provided data.
Some frameworks have objects inside of objects inside of objects, and so on. Normally kreXX does not run in circles, but going to deep inside of an object tree can result in a lot of output.
Here you can reset your local settings, which are stored in a cookie. kreXX will then use the global settings (either ini-file or factory settings).
kreXX can save it's output to a file, instead of outputting it to the frontend. The output will then be stored in the log folder.

A lot of output does not only slow down your server, it also slows down your browser. When using kreXX in a loop, it will create output every time the loop is executed. To limit this, you can configure the maximum call settings.
Here you can disable kreXX without uninstalling the whole module.
This is the folder where kreXX will store it's logfiles.
How many logfiles do you want to store inside your logging folder? When there are more files than this number, the older files will get deleted.
Choose a skin here. We have provided kreXX with two skins: smoky-grey and hans.

kreXX's configuration can be edited here, changes will be stored in a cookie and overwrite the ini and factory settings. Please note, that these are only local settings. They only affect this browser.

This option registers the fatal errorhandler as soon as kreXX is included. When a fatal error occures, kreXX will offer a backtrace and an analysis of the all objects in it. PHP always clears the stack in case of a fatal error, so kreXX has to keep track of it. Be warned: This option will dramatically slow down your requests. Use this only when you have to. It is by far better to register the errorhandler yourself with \krexx::registerFatal(); and later unregister it with \krexx::unregisterFatal(); tp prevent a slowdown.
kreXX tries to detect whether a request is made via ajax. When it is detected, it will do no output at all. The AJAX detection can be disabled here.

Shall kreXX do a "deep" analysis of the backtrace? Be warned, a deep analysis can produce a lot of output. A "normal" analysis will use the configured settings, while a "deep" analysis will get as much data from the objects as possible.
kreXX checks regularly how much memory is left. Here you can adjust the amount where it will trigger an emergency break. Unit of measurement is MB.
kreXX checks during the analysis how much time has elapsed since start. Here you can adjust the amount where it will trigger an emergency break. Unit of measurement is seconds.
Here you can toggle if kreXX shall analyse the methods of a class.
Here you can toggle if kreXX shall analyse the protected methods of a class. Of cause, they will only be analysed if kreXX is analysing class methods at all.
Here you can toggle if kreXX shall analyse the private methods of a class. Of cause, they will only be analysed if kreXX is analysing class methods at all.

Here you can edit the frontend configuration form.
= The value can be edited in the frontend.
= The value will only be displayed.
= kreXX will not display the value.
Edit local cookie settings
Normally, we would display the menu for the local cookie settings here. This menu is a part of the kreXX output and located in the footer.
The output of kreXX was disabled, so it will not be displayed.

Here you can edit the local cookie settings. They are stored in a cookie, and only affect your current browser. Unlike the configuration file, not all settings can be edited here by default. This can be changed in the
menu. Local cookie settings overwrite configuration file settings.
Please note, that these settings only affect your current browser!
Usage
kreXX will be called in the PHP source code:
Most of the time you will use this method. kreXX will analyse the $object and give you detailed information about it:
Public attributes of the object
Protected attributes of the object (can be toggled)
Private attributes of the object (can be toggled)
Content of the traversable part of the object (can be toggled)
Result of all configured debugging callbacks (can be configured)
In case the variable is not an object, it will simply display its content.
Start a benchmark:
Define a "moment" during a benchmark test. The $string should be something meaningful, like "Model invoice db call":
End the benchmark test and displays the result:
Outputs backtrace with sourcecode. When kreXX finds objects inside the backtrace, it will analyse them:
Register the fatal error handler in the system:
Unregister the fatal error handler in the system:
Mode datailed help
Documentation at Typo3 Docs
Documentation at sourceforge
Configuration
kreXX is already preconfigured, you don't have to configure it. But there are always moments when you want to change it. There are 3 levels of configuration:
1.) Factory settings
The factory settings are hardcoded fallback settings.
2.) Configuration file Krexx.ini
The configuration file settings are stored in the file Krexx.ini. kreXX shows in it's output footer where it is searching for this file. In typo3 this is normally:
You can edit these settings
here
Configuration file settings overwrite factory settings.
3.) Local cookie settings

You can edit the local cookie settings on the fly in the footer of the kreXX output. They are stored in a cookie, and only affect your current browser. Unlike the configuration file, not all settings can be edited there.
Local cookie settings overwrite configuration file settings.
Please note, that these are only local settings, only affecting your current browser.
